Good question. The most common way is to

What do you do? That's it. So simple.
Yes, it's very simple. You can also say,

Can I also ask what is your job? You

It's more relaxed and friendly.
Got it? So, what do you do? Is the best

The simplest way is to say I'm a plus

I'm a nurse. I work in a hospital. Or,

How do they answer?
Good question. You can say, "I'm looking

And what about students?
Students can say, "I'm a student. I

These are great. Notice how we use

That's right. Keep it simple and

work with.
Ah, yes. Your colleagues and co-workers.
Exactly. A colleague or co-orker is

And your boss is the person who manages

Right? If you are the boss, you can say
I manage a team of 10 people or I'm

What about working alone? Some people

True. If you work alone, you can say,

business."
Those are useful phrases. So, we have

self-employed people who work for

Exactly. Now, let's talk about work

You can answer by saying when you start

Some people work shifts. You can say I

And if your schedule changes, you can

I like flexible schedules. It means you

Me, too. Some jobs are full-time, which

So, you can say, "I work full-time or I

Perfect. Now, let's practice describing

Okay, let's hear it.

12. After lunch, I prepare materials for

That's a clear description. My turn. I

Definitely need coffee. I start working

by 6, but sometimes I work later if I
have a deadline.
Great. See how we used simple past and

Yes. It's not complicated. Just describe

Exactly. Now, let's talk about something

Okay, this is interesting. Not everyone

That's true. It's normal to like some

Good idea. When someone asks, "Do you

You can start with, "I really enjoy or I

really enjoy working with people or I
love the creative freedom.
Those sound natural. Can you give more

Sure. I like my co-workers. They're very

Every day is different.
What about the environment? I like

Perfect. And you can talk about the

Those are practical things. What about

Beautiful. Those are deeper, more

things you don't like?
Uh, yes, the challenges. You want to be

if you're talking to your boss.
Good point. So, how do you politely say
you don't like something? You can use
softer language. Instead of I hate, say,
I find it challenging or it can be
difficult when smart. So instead of I
hate working overtime, you say working
long hours can be tiring.
Exactly. Or instead of my boss is

communication with management is

That's much more professional. Give us
some common complaints that people have.
Okay. The commute is long. It takes me 2

Or the salary could be better. Or
there's not much room for growth in this
company.
Right? And some people say the work is

These are real problems that many people

If you don't like your job, what can you
do?
Well, you can try to improve the

Or you can look for a new job. You can
say, "I'm thinking about changing
careers, or I'm exploring new
opportunities."
That's right. It's okay to move on if
you're not happy. Life is too short to
stay in a job you hate.
Absolutely. Now let's talk about career
goals and ambitions.
Yes. When someone asks, "Where do you
see yourself in 5 years?" This is about
your future plans.
That's a classic interview question. How
do you answer it?
You can talk about your professional
goals. For example, I'd like to become a
manager or I hope to start my own
business
or I want to develop my skills in
marketing or I'm working towards a
promotion. Exactly. You can also mention
personal development. I want to learn
new languages or I plan to get a
master's degree.
These show that you're thinking about

it's also okay to say I'm happy where I
am or I just want to keep improving in
my current role.
Right? Not everyone wants to climb the

their current position. And that's

All right, everyone. This is one of the

Yes. And we want to help you avoid these

Mistake number one is huge. Many people
confuse work and job.
Oh, I think I know this one. Can you
explain the difference?
Sure. Job is a noun. It's the position
you have. Work can be a noun or a verb.
When it's a verb, it means the action of
doing your job.
So, I say I have a job, not I have a
work.
Exactly. And I go to work, not I go to
job. Common mistake.
So, what's your job is correct, but
what's your work sounds strange,
right? You can say what's your line of
work which means what industry are you
in but for the job title use what's your
job. This is so helpful. Okay. What's
mistake number two?
Mistake number two is using the wrong
article. In English we need a or an
before job titles.
Can you give examples?
Sure. Wrong. I am teacher. Correct. I am
a teacher. Wrong. She is engineer.
Correct. She is an engineer.
Ah, we need that little word. But wait,
when do we use an instead of uh?
Great question. Use an before vowel
sounds. So, an engineer, an accountant,
an artist, an office worker.
And uh before consonant sounds, a
teacher, a doctor, a manager, a
programmer. Perfect. Just don't forget
it completely. I am teacher is a very
common mistake.
Got it. What's mistake number three?
Mistake three is about saying where you
work. Many learners say I work in Google
or I work in Microsoft.
What's wrong with that?
We don't use in for companies. We say I
work at Google or I work for Microsoft.
So when do we use in? Use in for the
type of place or industry. I work in an
office. I work in a hospital. I work in
the tech industry.
Ah, so in is for the place type. At is
for the specific location and for is for
the company or person.
Exactly. I work in a bank means the
building. I work at Wells Fargo is the
specific bank. I work for the bank
manager is who employs me. This is so
clear. Now, what's mistake number four?
Mistake four, confusion with salary and
wage. They're similar, but different.
How are they different?
A salary is usually paid monthly or
yearly for professional jobs. A wage is
usually paid hourly or weekly for labor
jobs.
So, a teacher has a salary, but a waiter
has wages.
Exactly. You say, "My salary is $50,000
per year, but my wage is $15 per hour."
And most people don't talk about exact
numbers, right?
Correct. It's more polite to say, "I
earn a good salary or the pay is decent
rather than giving exact amounts
unless someone specifically asks or it's
a job interview negotiation."
Right? Okay. Mistake number five, mixing
up boss and manager. Wait, aren't they
the same?
They're similar, but boss is informal
and general. Manager is more specific
and professional.
So, in a job interview, I should say, I
reported to the sales manager, not I
reported to my boss.
Exactly. Boss is fine in casual
conversation, but use specific titles in
professional settings. My supervisor, my
manager, the department head.
That makes sense. What's mistake number
six? This one is about job searching.
People often say I'm searching job or
I'm finding job.
What should they say instead?
Say I'm looking for a job or I'm
searching for a job or I'm job hunting.
Don't forget or and a.
So I'm looking for a job in marketing is
correct.
Perfect. And if you already got the job,
you say, "I found a job," not I finded a
job. Found is the past tense of find.
Good reminder. Irregular verbs can be
tricky. What's mistake number seven?
Mistake seven is about experience.
People say, "I have 5 years of
experience," but then say, "I am
experience."
What's wrong with I am experience?
Experience is a noun, not an adjective.
You can't be experienced. You should say
I am experienced with ed at the end.
So I have five years of experience or I
am an experienced teacher.
Exactly. I am very experienced in this
field, not I am very experienced.
This is such a common mistake. I'm glad

Last mistake number eight, confusing
hire and rent. Hm. I thought they were
the same.
They're similar, but used differently.
Hire is for people or some services.
Rent is for objects or property.

Sure. The company hired five new

What about cars?
Ah, tricky one. In British English, it's

So, it's safer to say the company hired
